study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the hepatoprotective effects of grape juice prepared using low-speed masticating (LSM) and high-speed centrifugal (HSC) juicers in db/db mice.
results_summary: LSM grape juice significantly reduced hepatic triglycerides, serum aspartate transaminase activities, and insulin resistance, while HSC juice showed no significant effects. LSM juice also exhibited higher antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activities, likely due to its higher proanthocyanidin content.
population_specificity: Six-week-old db/db mice (a model for type 2 diabetes and obesity).
effective_dosage: Diet containing 1% freeze-dried LSM or HSC grape juice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of white grape juice (WGJ) supplementation on metabolic parameters, including body mass index, waist circumference, blood pressure, glucose, insulin, oxidative damage, and lipid profile in women.
results_summary: WGJ supplementation reduced body mass index, waist, and abdominal circumference but did not significantly affect blood pressure, glucose, insulin, or oxidative damage. It increased high-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels by 16%.
population_specificity: 25 women aged 50 to 67 years.
effective_dosage: 7 mL/kg/day of white grape juice (Vitis labrusca).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a pectinolytic enzyme preparation (PEP-N31) on phenolic content, methanol concentration, and color of grape juice compared to conventional and commercial enzyme treatments.
results_summary: PEP-N31 increased phenolic content (1637.21 mg.L-1) compared to conventional methods (1422.59 mg.L-1) and matched commercial enzyme results (1682.10 mg.L-1), while keeping methanol levels below 200 mg.L-1. The juice also showed improved yield and color characteristics.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on grape juice processing).
effective_dosage: Grapes were blanched for 3 min and macerated for 1 h with PEP-N31.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a Mediterranean diet versus a habitual high-fat American diet supplemented with fish oil, walnuts, and grape juice on weight and cardio-metabolic health in overweight or obese US adults.
results_summary: The study found that participants in the supplement arm (including grape juice) had significantly lower adiponectin levels compared to controls at 4 weeks, but no significant improvements in endothelial function or inflammatory biomarkers were observed. The Mediterranean diet showed more benefits than the supplemented diet.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese US adults (73% female, mean age 51 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the excretion of anthocyanins in urine after consumption of a mixed juice containing red grape juice, focusing on unmetabolised forms and glucuronide derivatives.
results_summary: The study found that anthocyanins from red grapes were excreted in urine (38 nmol, 0.22% of ingested dose), with unmetabolised delphinidin-3-glucoside excreted more than less polar anthocyanins. Excretion peaked between 2-4 hours post-consumption, and no significant difference was observed between strawberry and red grape anthocyanin excretion.
population_specificity: Human intervention study (specific demographics not detailed in abstract).
effective_dosage: Mixed juice containing 21.93 mg of anthocyanins (red grape portion not specified separately).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of pasteurization and high-power ultrasound treatment on the quality, bioactive compounds, and microbiological properties of red grape juice.
results_summary: Ultrasound treatment at 70% amplitude for 10 min preserved phenolic content similarly to pasteurization and retained higher levels of l-ascorbic acid. It also improved microbial inactivation and altered physicochemical properties like pH, soluble solids, and acidity.
population_specificity: Red grape juice samples (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: Ultrasound treatment at 50% and 70% amplitude for 5 and 10 min.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effect of sonication and chemical preservation on the nutritional properties of a grape-carrot juice blend.
results_summary: Sonication significantly enhanced the total phenolic, flavonoid, reducing power, and antioxidant properties of the juice blend, with improvements increasing over sonication time. The study also noted positive effects during a 90-day storage period at refrigerated temperatures.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on juice properties, not human subjects).
effective_dosage: 250 mL samples treated with sonication (20 kHz, 70% amplitude, 5 min at 15°C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the chemopreventive and anticancer properties of phenolic compounds in grape juice extracts (GJE) from Autumn Royal and Ribier varieties, focusing on their effects on colon cancer cell viability and metastatic potential.
results_summary: GJE reduced cell viability in colon cancer cell lines HT-29 and SW-480 in a dose-dependent manner, decreased cell migration and invasion, and diminished MMP-2 and MMP-9 gene expression, indicating potential anticancer properties.
population_specificity: Colon cancer cell lines (HT-29 and SW-480)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of whole red grape juice on resting blood pressure and post-exercise hypotension in individuals with hypertension.
results_summary: Grape juice reduced resting blood pressure in individuals with controlled initial BP but not in those with borderline hypertensive values. It also improved post-exercise hypotension in the controlled BP subgroup.
population_specificity: 26 individuals with hypertension, aged 40-59 years.
effective_dosage: 150 ml daily for men, 100 ml daily for women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of supercritical carbon dioxide technology (SCCD) on the characteristics of a whey-grape juice drink, focusing on physicochemical properties, bioactive compounds, and volatile compounds.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in pH, titratable acidity, soluble solids, total anthocyanin, and DPPH activity among SCCD treatments. However, ACE inhibitory activity increased with higher SCCD pressure, and minor differences in volatile compounds were noted, primarily the presence of ketones.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or lab-based study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether long-term grape juice concentrate (GJC) consumption could protect against cadmium-induced reproductive damage in rats, specifically focusing on sperm profile and epididymal morphology.
results_summary: The study found that GJC effectively reduced cadmium accumulation and lipid peroxidation, preserving sperm count, structure, and transit time while restoring epididymal morphology. These results suggest GJC may mitigate reproductive damage caused by cadmium intoxication.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (n=6 per group)
study_duration: From 50 to 136 days old (86 days total)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the quality effects of non-thermal high voltage atmospheric cold plasma (HVACP) treatment versus thermal pasteurization on white grape juice.
results_summary: HVACP treatment at 80 kV for 4 min effectively reduced microbial load without significantly altering pH, acidity, or electrical conductivity. While some antioxidant properties decreased, results were comparable to thermal pasteurization, with an observed increase in total flavonols.
population_specificity: White grape juice (no human or animal subjects mentioned).
study_duration: Single treatment session (duration not specified beyond minutes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-pressure processing (HPP) and thermal pasteurization (TP) on microbial levels, physicochemical properties, antioxidant content, and sensory attributes of white grape juice during refrigerated storage.
results_summary: HPP at 600 MPa effectively reduced microbial counts while better preserving physicochemical properties, antioxidant capacity, and sensory quality compared to TP. Sensory analysis showed no significant difference between HPP-treated juice and fresh juice, whereas TP reduced acceptance.
population_specificity: White grape juice samples (no human subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the stability of phenolic compounds, antioxidant activity, and color parameters of microencapsulated powdered BRS Violeta red grape juice under different storage conditions and carrier agent formulations.
results_summary: The study found that a specific treatment (1SM) preserved most anthocyanins, while other treatments showed increased p-coumaroylated anthocyanins and decreased flavonol content over time. Hydroxycinnamate content decreased across all treatments, and flavan-3-ols were lost at higher temperatures, but antioxidant activity and color remained stable after 150 days.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on grape juice powder)
effective_dosage: Not specified (carrier agent concentrations and proportions varied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of enzymatic treatment combined with Membrane Separation Process (MSP) in improving the physico-chemical characteristics of concentrated grape juice.
results_summary: The study found that enzymatic pretreatment with Novozym 33095(r) at 35°C, 15 min, and 50 mgL-1 yielded the best grape pulp characteristics. Subsequent MSP using 0.05 mm membrane pore size, 1 bar pressure, and 40°C treatment temperature achieved high permeate flux and suitable juice characteristics, while reverse osmosis at 40 bar and 40°C resulted in high soluble solids and low turbidity.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the dose-response relationship between Concord grape juice flavonoid intake and its effects on cardiovascular disease risk biomarkers.
results_summary: The study found correlations between grape juice flavonoid intake and improved flow-mediated vasodilation (FMD), with inverse dose-response relationships for blood pressure, platelet aggregation, and LDL oxidation resistance. These results suggest modest serving sizes of Concord grape juice may positively impact cardiovascular risk factors.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from clinical trial data).
effective_dosage: Not specified (analyzed data from studies with varying doses).
study_duration: Not specified (duration varied among analyzed trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grape juice concentrate (GJC) could protect against cadmium-induced testicular damage and spermatogenic disruption in rats.
results_summary: The study found that GJC consumption restored testicular morphology, reduced inflammation, and minimized ultrastructural damage caused by cadmium, suggesting protective effects against spermatogenic disruption.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (50 days old at study start, 136 days old at endpoint).
effective_dosage: 2 g/kg/day of G8000(®) grape juice concentrate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial effects of white grape juice extract (WGJe) against various bacteria, yeasts, and fungi, as well as its impact on bacterial biofilm formation.
results_summary: WGJe showed bacteriostatic and bactericidal activity, particularly against Gram-positive bacteria like Staphylococcus aureus (MIC 3.9 μg/mL) and inhibited biofilm formation in E. coli and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. No effect was observed on Candida sp. or Aspergillus niger (MIC > 2000 μg/mL).
population_specificity: In vitro bacterial and fungal strains (Gram-positive, Gram-negative, yeasts, and fungi).
effective_dosage: MIC values ranged from 3.9 μg/mL (S. aureus) to 2000 μg/mL (E. coli); bactericidal concentration was 500 μg/mL for some strains.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether purple grape juice could acutely improve cognition and mood in healthy young adults.
results_summary: Purple grape juice significantly improved reaction time on attention measures and increased calm ratings compared to placebo, but no significant effects were observed on memory measures. Order effects suggested enduring positive effects on pre-dose memory reaction time and post-dose calm ratings when grape juice was consumed first.
population_specificity: 20 healthy young adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of whole grape juice on cisplatin-induced acute gastrointestinal tract disorders and nephrotoxicity in Wistar rats.
results_summary: Whole grape juice improved gastric emptying and ghrelin mRNA expression in the stomach but did not reduce renal function markers in acute renal toxicity. It slightly improved some renal tubular changes but had no significant effect on oxidative stress/antioxidant status parameters.
population_specificity: Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of organic and conventional white grape juices on brain energy metabolism enzymes in rats with induced hepatic encephalopathy.
results_summary: Both organic and conventional white grape juices prevented the decrease in creatine kinase (CK) and pyruvate kinase (PK) activity caused by carbon tetrachloride (CCl4) in rat brain structures, suggesting a restorative effect on brain energy metabolism enzymes. No changes in feeding behavior were observed, but grooming behavior increased in the open field test.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (90-days-old)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether purple grape juice (pGJ) improves microvascular endothelial function and reduces oxidative stress and inflammation in childhood cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in endothelial function or changes in oxidative stress and inflammation markers after 4 weeks of pGJ consumption compared to clear apple juice.
population_specificity: Childhood cancer survivors aged 10-21 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate different methods (cold treatment, cream of tartar, CMC, and Mannoprotein) for stabilizing tartrate crystals in red grape juice.
results_summary: The study found that Mannoprotein and CMC were effective in stabilizing tartrate crystals in red grape juice, as evidenced by reduced sediment formation and changes in color indices, acidity, pH, and taste. Other methods were less successful.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely grape juice samples in a laboratory setting).
study_duration: Not specified (storage at 5°C to stimulate precipitation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a crude enzymatic extract from Kluyveromyces marxianus (EEB) and a commercial enzyme preparation (PEC) on the maceration, clarification, and quality of grape juice.
results_summary: Both EEB and PEC increased juice yield, reduced viscosity, and improved clarification, with PEC showing higher values for these parameters. However, EEB-treated juice exhibited better color intensity and higher extraction of phenolic compounds and anthocyanins.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on grape juice processing, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biocontrol potential of selected yeast strains against Aspergillus carbonarius and their ability to remove ochratoxin A (OTA) from grape juice.
results_summary: Two yeast strains (235 and 751) significantly inhibited A. carbonarius growth, while volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from all four yeasts prevented pathogen sporulation. Three strains (235, 751, and 778) efficiently adsorbed OTA from grape juice, with autoclaving improving adsorption capacity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and grape berry experiments)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether white grape juice extract (WGJe) could protect human renal proximal tubular cells from radiocontrast media-induced toxicity by modulating cell survival signaling pathways.
results_summary: WGJe pre-treatment improved cell viability after exposure to sodium diatrizoate, reversed the decrease in phosphorylation of Akt, FOXO1, and FOXO3a, and modulated other key signaling molecules involved in cell survival and death. However, WGJe also negatively affected phosphorylation of p38, NF-κB, and pERK1/2.
population_specificity: Human renal proximal tubular (HK-2) cells in vitro.
effective_dosage: Not specified (only concentration of sodium diatrizoate: 75 mgI/ml).
study_duration: Initial 2.5h exposure to diatrizoate, followed by 27.5h incubation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of UV-C irradiation on the inactivation of E. coli K-12 and the shelf life of freshly squeezed turbid white grape juice (FSWGJ).
results_summary: UV-C treatment reduced E. coli K-12 by 5.34 log cycles and extended the microbial shelf life of FSWGJ to 14 days at 4°C, though it adversely affected turbidity, color, and ascorbic acid content. Physicochemical properties were altered during storage, but pH, total soluble solids, and titratable acidity remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Freshly squeezed turbid white grape juice (FSWGJ) samples.
effective_dosage: UV dosage of 9.92 J/cm² (1.24 J/cm² per cycle) at a flow rate of 0.90 mL/s.
study_duration: 32 minutes of UV-C treatment (8 cycles of 244 s each).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether phenolic compounds in grape juice could reduce inflammatory effects in experimental colitis induced by TNBS in rats.
results_summary: Grape juice, particularly at 1% dose, reduced TNF-immunoexpression, iNOS, and COX-2, indicating anti-inflammatory effects. It also decreased genotoxicity in peripheral blood cells.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with induced colitis.
effective_dosage: 1% and 2% grape juice, administered 24 hours or 7 days after colitis induction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Concord grape juice (CGJ) could improve endothelial function and arterial stiffness in healthy smokers.
results_summary: CGJ significantly improved pre-smoking endothelial function (FMD) and arterial stiffness (PWV) compared to placebo. It also prevented acute smoking-induced impairments in these measures at days 7 and 14.
population_specificity: Healthy smokers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if post-harvest ultrasonication cleaning and incubation could increase resveratrol levels in grape juice without altering total soluble solids.
results_summary: Ultrasonication and incubation increased resveratrol levels by 1.53, 1.15, and 1.24 times in juice from Campbell Early, Muscat Bailey A, and Kyoho grapes, respectively, without changing total soluble solids. The method was effective for producing resveratrol-enriched juice while thoroughly cleaning grapes.
population_specificity: Three grape varieties (Campbell Early, Muscat Bailey A, Kyoho) were studied.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of grape juice on platelet enzyme activities and aggregation in diabetic rats, comparing it to red wine and specific polyphenols.
results_summary: Grape juice increased ectonucleotidase activities, prevented ADA activity elevation, and reduced platelet aggregation in diabetic rats. Polyphenols in grape juice also modulated enzyme activities and decreased platelet aggregation in vitro.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats (n=10 per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of grape juice on hemodynamics, baroreflex sensitivity, heart rate variability, blood pressure variability, and cardiac redox parameters in hypertensive rats.
results_summary: Grape juice treatment modulated autonomic function by altering heart rate variability components (lower normalized LF and higher HF) and improved cardiac redox status (higher GSH/GSSG ratio), though it did not significantly affect blood pressure or baroreflex sensitivity compared to resveratrol.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with L-NAME-induced hypertension.
effective_dosage: Not specified (grape juice was administered alongside L-NAME at 60 mg/kg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether organic purple grape juice (PGJ) could protect against oxidative stress caused by exhaustive exercise in rats.
results_summary: The study found that PGJ intake protected against oxidative damage in rat tissues, reducing TBARS levels and DCFH-DA oxidation while increasing Ca(2+)-ATPase activity. No significant adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Rats subjected to exhaustive exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effect of Öküzgözü grape juice against tissue damage induced by carbon tetrachloride (CCl₄) in rats, comparing its efficacy to ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA).
results_summary: Öküzgözü grape juice significantly reduced biochemical markers of tissue damage (ALT, AST, TB, MDA) and improved albumin levels, comparable to UDCA. Histopathological findings supported its protective effects against CCl₄-induced damage.
population_specificity: Rats exposed to CCl₄-induced tissue damage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if grape juice concentrate could protect the liver from high-fat diet-induced injury in rats by evaluating histopathological changes and immunohistochemistry markers.
results_summary: Grape juice concentrate did not significantly affect liver tissue in cholesterol-exposed rats but modulated p16 immunoexpression, suggesting a role in cell cycle control. No significant changes were observed for p53 and p21.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (n=18)
effective_dosage: 222 mg per day in drinking water

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effects of heat treatment on physicochemical characteristics and sensory properties of different fruit juice concentrates, including grape juice (pekmez).
results_summary: The study found that heat treatment affected viscosity, sensory properties, and hydroxymethyl furfural concentration in pekmez samples, with apricot and date pekmez scoring higher for odour, taste, and consistency. A Fuzzy Expert System (FES) was developed for prediction, showing statistical accordance with experimental results.
population_specificity: Not specified (fruit juice concentrates in general).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant effect of experimental grape juice by measuring urinary 6-sulfatoxymelatonin (aMT6-s) and total antioxidant capacity in individuals of different age groups.
results_summary: Grape juice consumption significantly increased urinary aMT6-s and total antioxidant capacity across all age groups compared to baseline and post-assay values, suggesting potential functional benefits. The study highlights the juice's nutraceutical properties and suitability for commercialization due to its high sensory and nutritional quality.
population_specificity: Young (20 ± 10 yr-old), middle-aged (45 ± 10 yr-old), and elderly (75 ± 10 yr-old) individuals.
effective_dosage: 200 mL twice a day (as lunch and dinner desserts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of apple and grape juice consumption on the body's antioxidant status in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found that 2 weeks of apple and grape juice consumption increased plasma total antioxidant capacity, decreased malondialdehyde concentration, and enhanced erythrocyte glutathione peroxidase and catalase activities, but did not affect plasma carbonyl content, superoxide dismutase activity, lymphocyte damage, or urinary 8-hydroxy-2-deoxyguanosine levels.
population_specificity: 25 healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether subchronic treatment with grape juice concentrate protects liver and peripheral blood cells against cholesterol-induced injury in rats.
results_summary: Grape juice concentrate did not significantly affect liver tissue but reduced oxidative DNA damage in peripheral blood cells induced by H2O2. COX-2 expression in the liver showed no significant differences between groups.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (n=18)
effective_dosage: 222 mg/d in drinking water for the final week
study_duration: 5 weeks (with grape juice concentrate administered only in the final week)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming grape juice could modify γδ T-cell function and other immune-related factors.
results_summary: Grape juice consumption significantly increased circulating γδ T-cell numbers and serum vitamin C levels, improved antioxidant activity, enhanced γδ T-cell proliferation, and reduced DNA strand breaks compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Healthy, middle-aged human subjects (n=85).
effective_dosage: 100% grape juice made from Concord grapes, consumed daily (exact volume not specified).
interactions: Subjects were asked not to consume other red, blue, or purple fruits during the study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a method for quantifying volatile and nonvolatile biogenic amines in grape juices and Port wines, and to assess the concentration of these amines in grape juice and Port wines with different aging times.
results_summary: The study developed a reliable method for quantifying 22 biogenic amines in grape juice and Port wines, finding low total amine content in Port wines and a decrease in amine levels with aging. The method demonstrated excellent analytical characteristics in terms of linearity, recovery, repeatability, and detection limits.
population_specificity: Grape juice and Port wine samples (no human subjects).

study_goal: To determine the feasibility and effects of Concord grape juice as an adjunctive treatment for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV), and assess its impact on quality of life and psychological state.
results_summary: Grape juice reduced nausea and vomiting frequency, duration, and distress, but high attrition limited statistical significance. Baseline anxiety, depression, and hostility were linked to worse CINV outcomes.
population_specificity: 77 adult cancer patients receiving moderately or highly emetogenic chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 4 oz. of grape juice or placebo before meals for one week post-chemotherapy.
study_duration: One week following each of four chemotherapy cycles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of thermal processing conditions on green leaf volatiles (GLVs), total phenols, monomeric anthocyanins, and percent polymeric color in Concord grape juice, as well as the effects of fruit maturity and juice processing stages on GLV content.
results_summary: The study found that trans-2-hexenal levels were highest immediately after crushing and decreased during processing, with hot break conditions leading to higher concentrations in the final juice. No significant increase in phenolics and anthocyanins was observed under hot break conditions, and different pasteurization regimes did not significantly affect GLV content.
population_specificity: Concord grape juice processing stages (crushing, depectinization, pressing, pasteurization, cold-stabilization).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (processing conditions assessed, not dosage).
study_duration: Not specified (processing stages evaluated, not duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a single administration of purple grape juice on the oral bioavailability of cyclosporin A (CyA) in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: Purple grape juice significantly decreased cyclosporine AUC by 30% and Cmax by 28%, suggesting it affects absorption rather than elimination. The findings indicate that consuming CyA with purple grape juice may reduce drug bioavailability, potentially leading to subtherapeutic blood levels.
population_specificity: 12 healthy male volunteers (mean age 20.6 years, range 19-23).
effective_dosage: 200 mL of purple grape juice administered once with 200-mg CyA soft-gelatin capsules.
study_duration: Single administration with a 1-week washout period between treatments.
interactions: Purple grape juice significantly decreased cyclosporin A bioavailability, suggesting a clinically relevant interaction. A 2-hour free interval between CyA intake and grape juice consumption is recommended.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the presence of beta-D-glucopyranoside of guaiacol in grape juice following grapevine exposure to smoke and assess its behavior under different treatments.
results_summary: The study found that grape juice from smoke-exposed grapes contained significant amounts of the glucoside, which was less susceptible to acid treatment but disappeared after enzyme treatment with beta-glucosidase. This suggests glucosylation of guaiacol occurs post-smoke exposure, potentially releasing guaiacol during fermentation.
population_specificity: Grapes (juice samples) exposed to bushfire smoke and experimental smoke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the metabolic impact of polyphenol-rich grape juice extract (GJX) and a red wine-grape juice mix (MIX) using metabolomics to identify differences in urinary biomarkers.
results_summary: Both GJX and MIX significantly altered urinary metabolic profiles compared to placebo, with MIX showing a 35% increase in hippuric acid excretion. GJX and MIX elevated 18 phenolic acids, with syringic acid and hydroxyhippuric acids being strong markers, though their effects on endogenous metabolites differed slightly.
population_specificity: 58 men and women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of organic and conventional purple grape juices against oxidative damage caused by carbon tetrachloride (CCl(4)) in brain, liver, and plasma of adult Wistar rats.
results_summary: Both organic and conventional grape juices reduced lipid peroxidation in cerebral cortex and hippocampus, while only organic grape juice reduced it in striatum and substantia nigra. Both juices also reduced CCl(4)-induced increases in catalase and superoxide dismutase activity in certain brain structures and showed antigenotoxic activity by reducing DNA damage.
population_specificity: Adult Wistar rats (7 months old)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of sonication (amplitude level and treatment time) on anthocyanin retention and color parameters in grape juice.
results_summary: Sonication significantly retained anthocyanins (CA: 97.5%, MA: 48.2%, DA: 80.9%) and strongly correlated with color parameters (L*, a*, b*, CI). Prediction models were accurate and statistically significant (p<0.05).
population_specificity: Grape juice samples (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: Amplitude level (24.4-61.0µm), treatment time (0-10min), frequency (20kHz), pulse durations (5s on/5s off)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of ozonation on grape juice color values and anthocyanin content.
results_summary: Ozonation significantly reduced anthocyanin content, with cyanidin-3-O-glucoside being more stable than other anthocyanins. Color values (L, a, b) and total color difference followed zero- or first-order kinetics during ozonation.
population_specificity: Grape juice samples
effective_dosage: Ozone concentration (1.6-7.8% w/w), treatment time (0-10 min)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acute effects of grape juice consumption on appetite, mood, and implicit memory during the post-lunch dip period.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between grape juice and placebo in mood, implicit memory, appetite, or food intake after lunch. Mood decreased over time for both treatments.
population_specificity: 35 participants with a mean age of 26 years who smoked an average of 11 cigarettes/day for 8 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of pulsed electric field (PEF) processing parameters in inactivating spoilage microorganisms in grape juice.
results_summary: PEF treatments effectively inactivated yeast and bacteria in grape juice, with reductions ranging from 2.24 to 3.94 log units. Optimal microbial inactivation was predicted at 35.0 kV cm(-1), 303 Hz pulse width for 1 ms, with maximum efficacy observed around 1500 MJ L(-1).
population_specificity: Spoilage microorganisms (Kloeckera apiculata, Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Lactobacillus plantarum, Lactobacillus hilgardii, Gluconobacter oxydans) in grape juice.
effective_dosage: 35.0 kV cm(-1), 303 Hz pulse width for 1 ms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of concentrated red grape juice (RGJ) and vitamin E on neutrophil NADPH oxidase activity and cardiovascular risk factors in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: RGJ reduced total cholesterol and apolipoprotein B while increasing HDL cholesterol, and both RGJ and vitamin E lowered oxidized LDL and neutrophil NADPH oxidase activity. Combined supplementation intensified these effects and reduced inflammatory biomarkers.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the interaction of polyphenols in grape juice with soluble carbohydrate polymers and lipid nanovesicles, and how these interactions affect polyphenol availability and functionality.
results_summary: The study found that a significant portion of polyphenols in grape juice are bound to macromolecules, affecting their absorption and functionality. Treatment with specific enzymes and detergents altered the release and composition of these polyphenols, suggesting qualitative differences between bound and free forms.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grape juice inhibits CYP2C9 activity, potentially affecting warfarin metabolism.
results_summary: Grape juice reduced CYP2C9 activity in vitro but did not alter flurbiprofen clearance in humans, making a pharmacokinetic interaction with warfarin unlikely.
population_specificity: 14 healthy volunteers
interactions: None mentioned in humans (only in vitro interaction noted)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the heat resistance of Escherichia coli O157:H7, Salmonella, and Listeria monocytogenes in white grape juice concentrate under different physiological conditions.
results_summary: The study found that E. coli O157:H7 was the most heat-resistant pathogen, while Salmonella was the most sensitive. A heat treatment of 1.5 min at 71.1°C was calculated to inactivate 5 log units of all three pathogens in white grape juice concentrate.
population_specificity: Pathogens (E. coli O157:H7, Salmonella, Listeria monocytogenes) in white grape juice concentrate.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on heat treatment parameters).
study_duration: Not applicable (study focused on heat resistance testing).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Concord grape juice consumption could lower blood pressure in hypertensive patients.
results_summary: Concord grape juice significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure in hypertensive patients after 8 weeks, with greater reductions compared to placebo. The placebo group showed smaller, less significant changes.
population_specificity: Hypertensive patients (40 subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily grape juice supplementation could reduce cellular DNA damage and free radical levels in healthy adults.
results_summary: Grape juice consumption significantly reduced lymphocyte DNA damage and ROS levels by 15%, suggesting increased plasma antioxidant capacity and potential cancer-protective effects. The preventive effect was consistent across both sexes.
population_specificity: 67 healthy adults (16 women, 51 men) aged 19-57 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grape juice could inactivate human enteroviruses and prevent or modify infections.
results_summary: Grape juice inactivated human enteroviruses in vitro but not parainfluenza type 1 virus. Inactivated virus could be reactivated by certain treatments, suggesting grape juice may not prevent intestinal infection.
population_specificity: In vitro study (human enteroviruses and host cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate different sample preparation methods for determining calcium content in grape juice and other beverages using flame atomic absorption spectrometry.
results_summary: The study found that mineralization with nitric acid at 80°C for 15 minutes provided the most satisfactory results for calcium determination in grape juice, with high accuracy (98.70-99.90%) and precision (relative standard deviation of 2.46%). Grape juice had a calcium content of 90.00 ± 20.40 mg/L.
population_specificity: Commercial grape juice, wines, and alcoholic beverages produced in Spain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the mutagenicity of commercially available white grape juice using the Ames mutagenicity test.
results_summary: The study found that white grape juice elicited a positive mutagenic response in Salmonella typhimurium strains, indicating the presence of direct-acting genotoxic components. The response was consistent across different brands and not influenced by an activation system, histidine residues, or sulfite treatment.
population_specificity: Salmonella typhimurium bacterial strains (TA104, TA97, TA98, TA100, TA1530).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grape juice consumption significantly impacts the effectiveness of dental bleaching compared to a white diet.
results_summary: The study found that grape juice consumption did not significantly affect dental bleaching efficacy compared to a white diet, with similar color change outcomes observed. The evidence quality was moderate, supporting the conclusion that dietary pigment restriction is unnecessary.
population_specificity: Participants undergoing dental bleaching (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Concord grape juice (CGJ) consumption increased serum metabolite bioavailability and improved cognitive performance in Veterans with Gulf War Illness (GWI).
results_summary: CGJ consumption was associated with significantly higher levels of three metabolites and correlated with improved cognitive function, as measured by changes in serum levels of epicatechin-sulphate and petunidin-glucuronide.
population_specificity: Veterans with Gulf War Illness (GWI)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic consumption of grape juice and other fruit forms improves cognition and mood in adults.
results_summary: One study supplementing grape juice found a trend for mood improvement, but the meta-analysis did not sufficiently support a role for grape juice or other fruit forms to improve cognition and mood.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥18 years
study_duration: ≥1 week (exact duration not specified for grape juice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate different sample preparation methods for determining iron content in grape juice and other beverages using atomic absorption spectrometry.
results_summary: The study found that wet mineralization with heated acid (HNO3-H2SO4) provided the best results for iron determination in grape juice, with high accuracy (97.5-101.6%) and precision (relative standard deviation of 3.51%). Iron levels in grape juice were measured at 3.394 +/- 2.15 mg/L.
population_specificity: Commercial grape juice, wines, and alcoholic beverages produced in Spain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grape juice consumption could improve oxidative stress parameters and physical performance in judo athletes.
results_summary: Grape juice consumption improved upper limb strength, reduced lipid and DNA damage, and lowered superoxide dismutase activity compared to placebo in judo athletes after combat simulations.
population_specificity: Twenty judo athletes in a randomized, double-blind clinical trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming Concord grape juice during cancer treatment could help prevent recurrence, treatment-related toxicity, or improve prognosis.
results_summary: The study included Concord grape juice as one of the specific foods analyzed in randomized controlled trials, suggesting potential benefits in ameliorating cancer treatment-related toxicities, but did not provide detailed results specific to grape juice.
population_specificity: Cancer patients (no specific type or age restriction mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of purple grape juice consumption on oxidative stress, inflammation, muscle damage, histone H4 acetylation, and muscle strength/power in volleyball athletes.
results_summary: Grape juice significantly reduced lipid peroxidation and DNA damage post-exercise but did not affect IFN-γ, IL-4, CK-NAC, or histone H4 acetylation. Lower limb power improved after acute exercise in both grape juice and control conditions.
population_specificity: 12 male volleyball players (16 ± 0.6 years old).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety, tolerability, and potential cognitive and fatigue improvements from daily Concord grape juice consumption in veterans with Gulf War Illness.
results_summary: The study found no significant unadjusted differences between grape juice and placebo groups in efficacy measures, but regression models showed statistically significant improvement in one cognitive test (RCAT) for the grape juice group. No dropouts were due to side effects, and adherence was high.
population_specificity: U.S. veterans diagnosed with Gulf War Illness (GWI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical relevance of food-drug interactions, specifically focusing on the effects of grape juice on drug bioavailability and toxicity.
results_summary: The study found that grape juice increased the bioavailability and toxicity of certain drugs like felodipine, nifedipine, saquinavir, and sildenafil, indicating significant pharmacokinetic interactions.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human population inferred from clinical interaction studies).
interactions: Increased bioavailability/toxicity of felodipine, nifedipine, saquinavir, and sildenafil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of grape juice polyphenols (GJPs) on endothelial function, blood pressure, heart rate, and sleep parameters in patients with severe obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of GJPs on endothelial function or blood pressure, but a significant reduction in heart rate compared to placebo. GJPs also led to a decrease in total sleep time without affecting sleep stages.
population_specificity: Adults with severe OSA (median AHI 43/h), predominantly male (75%), median age 61 years, and BMI 30.6 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of resveratrol, found in grape juice, in improving inflammatory disorders involving the intestinal mucosa, particularly in the context of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: The study found that resveratrol may down-regulate mediators of intestinal immunity in rodent models, but only two human intervention studies have explored its potential to improve IBD conditions, suggesting further clinical trials are needed.
population_specificity: Rodent models and limited human subjects with IBD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute consumption of organic and conventional grape juices from Vitis labrusca L. could beneficially affect redox homeostasis by influencing antioxidant biomarkers in healthy individuals.
results_summary: Both organic and conventional grape juices significantly increased levels of reduced glutathione, serum total antioxidant capacity, and activity of antioxidant enzymes (catalase, superoxide dismutase, glutathione peroxidase) compared to water, with no significant differences between juice types. No significant effects were observed on glucose or uric acid levels.
population_specificity: 24 healthy individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of Concord grape juice (CGJ) on smoking-induced impairment of inflammatory and fibrinolytic status in healthy smokers.
results_summary: CGJ consumption reduced baseline levels of inflammatory (sICAM-1) and fibrinolytic (PAI-1) markers and attenuated acute smoking-induced increases in these markers compared to placebo. The findings suggest CGJ improves cardiovascular risk factors in smokers.
population_specificity: Healthy smokers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of grape extracts, including grape juice alone, on blood pressure and vascular function in mildly hypertensive subjects.
results_summary: The grape-wine extract significantly reduced 24-hour ambulatory systolic/diastolic blood pressure and decreased endothelin-1 levels, while grape juice extract alone had no effect on blood pressure or vascular function.
population_specificity: 60 untreated, mildly hypertensive subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of grape polyphenols, including those in grape juice, for preventing or treating carcinogenesis.
results_summary: The study suggests grape polyphenols may have anticancer properties, supported by molecular data from in vivo and in vitro test systems, indicating potential for prevention and therapeutic use.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vivo and in vitro test systems).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the chemopreventive potential of polyphenols, including those in grape juice, against oral carcinogenesis using in-vivo and in-vitro test systems.
results_summary: Polyphenols demonstrated chemopreventive effects by inducing cellular death, apoptosis, inhibiting tumor growth, and exhibiting antioxidative properties. The findings suggest polyphenols could be a promising therapeutic approach for oral cancer prevention.
population_specificity: In-vivo and in-vitro test systems (not human-specific).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily consumption of 100% Concord grape juice improves lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in men over 45 years old.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in LUTS improvement between the grape juice and placebo groups after 3 months. There was no correlation between antioxidant levels and symptom changes, though a statistical difference was noted in uroflow rates.
population_specificity: Men over 45 years with significant lower urinary tract symptoms.
effective_dosage: 240 ml daily of 100% Concord grape juice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biological effects of grape polyphenols, including antioxidant properties and potential health benefits, and review recent patents related to their pharmaceutical applications.
results_summary: The study found that grape polyphenols exhibit antioxidant properties, support endothelial function, increase antioxidant capacity, protect against LDL oxidation, and have neuroprotective effects. Recent patents indicate a trend toward natural extraction methods and increased pharmaceutical use of grape juice and polyphenol-rich products.
population_specificity: Human and experimental models (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neurocognitive effects of Concord grape juice supplementation in older adults with early memory decline.
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in verbal learning and non-significant enhancement in verbal and spatial recall, with no effect on depressive symptoms, weight, or waist circumference. A small increase in fasting insulin was observed in the grape juice group.
population_specificity: Older adults with memory decline but not dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acute and long-term effects of grape juice consumption on endothelial function in adolescents with metabolic syndrome and compare its effects to pomegranate juice.
results_summary: Grape juice significantly improved flow-mediated dilation at 4 hours and 1 month, with the change at 1 month being significant only in the grape juice group. Both juices improved endothelial function, but grape juice showed sustained benefits over time.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 12-15 years with metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: 18 millilitre per kilogram per day of natural grape juice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of phenolic-rich grape juice, with or without alcohol, on vascular endothelial function in the postprandial state.
results_summary: Grape juice and grape juice plus alcohol significantly improved flow-mediated dilatation (FMD) compared to water, with no significant difference between the two grape juice treatments. Plasma glucose, TAG, and NEFA levels were similar across all treatments.
population_specificity: Ten subjects (specific demographics not provided).
effective_dosage: Not specified (test drink was red grape juice or red grape juice plus alcohol (12% v/v)).
study_duration: Single meal intervention with measurements taken up to 60 minutes post-consumption.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether incorporating grape pomace extracts into biodegradable starch-based films could enhance their physicochemical properties and introduce pH-sensing capabilities.
results_summary: The study found that grape pomace extracts improved the films' functional properties, including solubility, moisture content, and water vapor permeability, and provided a visual pH-sensing response (color changes from purple to green). The films demonstrated good colorimetric responses for pH indication, suggesting potential for food freshness monitoring.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on biodegradable films)
study_duration: Plasma treatment for 20 minutes (intervention duration not specified for extracts)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate grape pomace as a natural adsorbing/decontaminating material for removing Ochratoxin A (OTA) and assess its impact on wine metabolic profiles.
results_summary: Grape pomace effectively adsorbed OTA without significantly affecting wine quality, though it led to a reduction in some aromatic compounds. Activated carbon treatment resulted in a more pronounced impoverishment of the wine's metabolomic profile compared to grape pomace.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or wine samples).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of extractable polyphenols (EPPs) and non-extractable polyphenols (NEPPs) from grape pomace as a treatment for obesity and associated metabolic alterations in an animal model.
results_summary: The study found that EPPs significantly reduced weight gain (9.6%) and body mass index (9.7%), while NEPPs significantly reduced liver triglyceride levels (47%). Neither treatment improved insulin resistance.
population_specificity: Obese rats with insulin resistance.
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg of EPPs or NEPPs fractions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of dietary supplementation with 'Arinto' and 'Touriga Nacional' grape pomace flour on glycemic control, lipid metabolism, oxidative stress, and pancreatic health in a T2DM animal model.
results_summary: Supplementation with both grape pomace flours mitigated glycemic and lipid disruptions, reduced oxidative stress, and protected pancreatic β-cells in T2DM rats. The effects were comparable to metformin in some aspects.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats with induced T2DM (high-fat diet + streptozotocin).
effective_dosage: 10% of diet as grape pomace flour (specific frequency not stated).
study_duration: 28 days (supplementation duration not explicitly stated but inferred from protocol).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of red grape pomace (RGP) as a natural preservative in dry-cured sausages, comparing its efficacy to synthetic additives like ascorbic acid and nitrites.
results_summary: RGP reduced pH and promoted lactic acid bacteria growth similarly to synthetic additives but did not achieve the same red color. It slightly reduced lipid and protein oxidation, suggesting partial nitrite substitution potential.
population_specificity: Dry-cured sausages (salchichón).
effective_dosage: Low level (0.5%) and high level (1%) of RGP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antitumor effects of a Sicilian grape pomace hydroalcoholic extract (HE) on colon and breast cancer cells, focusing on mechanisms like apoptosis and autophagy.
results_summary: The extract reduced viability more effectively in colon cancer cells, inducing apoptosis, while breast cancer cells showed resistance and pro-survival autophagy. ROS levels increased in both cell types, but autophagy inhibition enhanced HE effects in breast cancer cells.
population_specificity: Colon and breast cancer cell lines (in vitro study).
study_duration: Up to 24 hours (time points varied for ROS and autophagy assessments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether biological treatment of grape pomace with Trametes versicolor under solid-state fermentation conditions could improve the extractability of bioactive compounds and enhance its nutritional composition.
results_summary: The study found that biological treatment significantly increased the activity of lignolytic and hydrolytic enzymes, improved the chemical composition (higher ash, crude protein, and free fat content), and enhanced the extractability of 13 individual phenolic compounds in grape pomace.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory-scale study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate grape pomace from two varieties (Becuet and Moscato) as rearing substrates for black soldier fly larvae (BSFL), focusing on larval growth performance, proximate composition, and fatty acid profile.
results_summary: BSFL reared on Becuet grape pomace showed a higher growth rate compared to Moscato. The rearing substrate did not significantly affect the proximate composition of BSFL, but Moscato-fed BSFL had higher total lipids and specific fatty acid profiles, including conjugated linoleic acid (CLA) isomers.
population_specificity: Black soldier fly larvae (BSFL)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antibacterial effects of polyphenolic extracts from Aglianico grape pomace against foodborne pathogens and their potential to reduce antibiotic resistance and inhibit biofilm formation.
results_summary: The study found that grape pomace extracts exhibited variable bacteriostatic and bactericidal effects against Gram-positive (Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus cereus) and Gram-negative (Escherichia coli, Salmonella Typhimurium) pathogens. The extracts also reduced the inhibitory concentration of standard antibiotics and inhibited biofilm development by S. aureus and B. cereus.
population_specificity: In vitro study on bacterial pathogens (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of in ovo feeding of grape pomace extract on hatchability, productive performance, immune response, and antioxidant status in broiler chickens.
results_summary: Grape pomace extract, particularly at 4 mg dosage, significantly improved body weight, reduced cholesterol levels, enhanced antioxidant capacity, and boosted immune response (IgM and IgG levels) in broiler chicks. The 4 mg dose was more effective than 2 mg or 6 mg doses.
population_specificity: Fertile broiler eggs (Arbor Acres strain) and hatched chicks raised until 5 weeks of age.
effective_dosage: 2 mg, 4 mg, and 6 mg grape pomace extract dissolved in DMSO, administered once on the 17.5th day of incubation.
study_duration: Intervention administered once; effects monitored until 5 weeks post-hatch.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Malbec grape pomace as a functional ingredient in bakery foods, assessing its impact on phenolic compounds, nutritional properties, and sensory attributes.
results_summary: Grape pomace increased dietary fiber, proteins, ash, total phenolic content, antiradical capacity, and anthocyanins while reducing carbohydrates. The supplemented foods provided sufficient bioactive compounds per portion to meet daily recommendations and were well-received by consumers, with biscuits being the most acceptable.
population_specificity: General consumers (sensory evaluation participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a green solvent system for extracting polyphenol-rich extracts from red grape pomace (RGP) with enhanced antioxidant properties.
results_summary: The optimized treatment yielded high polyphenol, pigment, and flavanol content, with extracts showing significantly enhanced antioxidant activity, attributed to compounds like catechin.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on grape pomace).
effective_dosage: Not specified (extraction process described, not dosage for consumption).
study_duration: Not specified (focused on extraction process optimization).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant capacity and ACE inhibitory potential of high-phenolic-content extracts from red grape pomace, comparing enzymatic and non-enzymatic extraction methods.
results_summary: Enzymatic extraction recovered 70% more phenolic compounds and significantly increased ACE inhibitory potential, though total phenolic content and antioxidant capacity did not differ statistically between extraction methods. The study highlights grape pomace's potential for bioactive compound recovery and environmental impact reduction.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiviral potential of Taurisolo®, a polyphenol-based nutraceutical derived from grape pomace, against HSV-1 and HSV-2 infections.
results_summary: Taurisolo® demonstrated inhibitory activity against HSV-1 and HSV-2 by blocking viral infection during early phases, as confirmed by plaque assays, real-time PCR, TEM, and fluorescence microscopy. The extract showed effectiveness both when added with the virus and when the virus was pretreated.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grape pomace could improve inflammation, gut barrier function, meat quality, and growth performance in finishing pigs.
results_summary: Grape pomace significantly reduced water loss, inflammatory markers (IL-1β, DAO, ROS, MDA), and harmful bacteria (Treponema, Streptococcus), while increasing immune markers (IgA, IgG, IgM, IFN-γ) and antioxidant activity (CAT, T-AOC, SOD). It also improved gut barrier function by enhancing occludin expression.
population_specificity: Finishing pigs

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of feeding a high amount of grape pomace in finishing cattle diets on carcass traits, product quality, and fatty acid composition of beef.
results_summary: Feeding grape pomace reduced lipid oxidation in beef over time, improved sensory quality (brightness and redness), and increased beneficial fatty acids like CLA and PUFA, though it limited growth performance in cattle.
population_specificity: Jersey × Holstein cross cattle (n = 24)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of grape pomace polyphenols as a therapeutic agent for managing oxidative stress and inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that grape pomace polyphenols demonstrated significant antioxidant effects (reducing reactive oxygen species and increasing glutathione levels) and anti-inflammatory actions (inhibiting inflammatory pathways and markers like IL-8, TNF-α, and C-reactive protein) in both in vitro and in vivo settings. The results suggest grape pomace could serve as an adjuvant treatment to reduce oxidative stress and chronic inflammation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo models, but no human population details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of Nasco pomace extract, delivered via nutriosomes, in a mouse model of Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: Nasco nutriosomes significantly prevented dopaminergic neuron degeneration in the brain regions affected by PD, outperforming the suspension form, which only showed effects in one region. The study validated nutriosomes as an effective nano-drug delivery system for enhancing polyphenol bioavailability.
population_specificity: Subacute MPTP-induced Parkinson's disease mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate grape pomace hydrolysate as a sole growth medium for bacterial cellulose production by acetic acid bacteria, optimizing its preparation for cost-effective industrial use.
results_summary: The study identified Komagataeibacter melomenusus AV436T as the most efficient bacterial cellulose producer in grape pomace hydrolysate, achieving up to 1.24 g/L dry membrane in 4 days. The produced membranes showed reduced crystallinity, altered thermal stability, and lower mechanical properties compared to those made in a complex medium.
population_specificity: Acetic acid bacteria strains, specifically Komagataeibacter species.
effective_dosage: Not specified (hydrolysate preparation optimized for reducing sugar and phenolic content).
study_duration: 4 days (1 day shaking, 3 days static incubation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether solid-state fermentation (SSF) with filamentous fungi could improve the recovery of bioactive phenolic compounds from grape pomace.
results_summary: The study found that SSF with certain fungi, particularly Pleurotus eryngii and Rhizopus oryzae, significantly increased the recovery of 17 phenolic compounds, with ellagic acid showing an 8.8-fold increase. The nutrient composition of grape pomace was also positively affected by the biological treatments.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using grape pomace as substrate)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary supplementation with grape pomace extract on broiler chickens' performance, meat quality, immune response, and transcriptional changes.
results_summary: Grape pomace supplementation significantly improved final live weight and daily weight gain in chickens compared to control and chestnut wood extract diets. It also promoted immune responses in the intestinal mucosa, with no observed effect on meat quality.
population_specificity: 864 broiler chickens (both sexes) from hatching to 45 days of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of grape pomace (GP) and grape extract (GE) on egg production, quality, and oxidative stability in laying hens.
results_summary: GP and GE improved some egg quality traits (e.g., yolk color, Haugh units) and oxidative stability but reduced average egg weight and protein digestibility. GP at 60 g/kg increased polyunsaturated fatty acids and reduced lipid oxidation in stored eggs.
population_specificity: Laying hens
effective_dosage: GP at 30 or 60 g/kg; GE at 0.5 or 1.0 g/kg

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether red grape pomace extracts, rich in polyphenols, could enhance the reparative effects of endothelial colony forming cells (ECFCs) under oxidative stress conditions.
results_summary: The study found that ethanolic extracts of red grape pomace at low concentrations improved the angiogenic capacities of ECFCs, reduced proliferation, apoptosis, and the inflammatory response of these cells, though mango leaves extract showed the most promising results.
population_specificity: In vitro study using endothelial colony forming cells (ECFCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of grape pomace (GP) alone or combined with feruloyl esterase-producing Lactobacillus plantarum A1 (Lp A1) on ensiling characteristics, ruminal fermentation, methane emissions, and microbiota in alfalfa silage.
results_summary: GP reduced ruminal total gas, methane production, nitrogen degradation, and methanogenic archaea but also decreased silage dry matter (DM) digestibility. When combined with Lp A1 (LG), it balanced proteolysis, improved DM digestibility, and reduced methane emissions compared to GP alone.
population_specificity: Alfalfa silage (in vitro ruminal fermentation context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of grape pomace and grapeseed extracts as sources of bioactive compounds for use in cosmetics, focusing on antioxidant and antimicrobial properties.
results_summary: The study found that grape pomace and grapeseed extracts exhibited high antioxidant capacity (90.8% and 87.5% DPPH inhibition, respectively) and inhibited the growth of Staphylococcus aureus and Staphylococcus epidermidis. The extracts were successfully incorporated into face cream formulations and remained stable for 35 days, suggesting their potential as natural replacements for synthetic antioxidants in cosmetics.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and formulation testing)
effective_dosage: Not specified (extract yields provided: 18.4% for grape pomace, 17.4% for grapeseed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether regular consumption of grape pomace-derived seasonings could help control hypertension and glycaemia, particularly in high-risk cardiovascular and healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found that grape pomace seasoning significantly reduced blood pressure and fasting blood glucose levels. It also modulated gut microbiota and bacterial communities, suggesting potential cardiometabolic benefits.
population_specificity: High-risk cardiovascular subjects (n = 17) and healthy subjects (n = 12).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a nanoplatform using polyphenol-rich grape pomace extracts to counteract oxidative stress and neurodegeneration in Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The nanoplatform successfully reduced ROS levels, prevented α-synuclein fibril aggregation, and restored cell viability in an in vitro PD model. The study suggests potential for preclinical translation.
population_specificity: In vitro model of Parkinson's disease (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate grape pomace (GP) as an alternative to in-feed antibiotics in broiler chickens, assessing its effects on growth, gut health, microbiota, blood parameters, and meat quality.
results_summary: GP improved gut morphology (increased villus height and VH:crypt depth ratio) and modified cecal microbiota (higher Bacteroidetes and Bacteroides/Lactobacillus abundance) without adverse effects on growth performance or meat quality. Blood biochemical profiles showed higher plasma Ca and P and reduced aspartate transaminase in GP-fed birds.
population_specificity: One-day-old Cobb-500 broiler chickens (576 birds total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how instant controlled pressure drop (DIC) treatment affects extractable and non-extractable polyphenol contents in grape pomace, considering pressure, cycles, and grape variety.
results_summary: The study found that DIC treatment increased extractable polyphenol (EPP) content, influenced by pressure, cycles, and initial polyphenol levels, while proanthocyanidin changes depended mainly on pressure and cycles. Grape pomace origin also affected EPP extraction.
population_specificity: Grape pomace from Malbec, Merlot, and Syrah varieties.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of grape pomace for treating NAFLD at different severity levels and to clarify its mechanism of action.
results_summary: Grape pomace reduced food intake, body weight gain, and serum leptin, improved glucose tolerance and insulin sensitivity, and reduced hepatic steatosis and inflammation. However, it was ineffective in reversing advanced NASH-related hepatic damage.
population_specificity: C57Bl/6 mice fed high-fat or western diets as models of obesity, hepatic steatosis, or steatohepatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effect of grape pomace supplementation on miRNA expression and its potential relationship with improved glycemic control in subjects with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: Grape pomace supplementation led to changes in specific miRNAs (miR-23a, miR-181a, miR-30c, and miR-222), with reductions in miR-30c and miR-222 associated with improved glycemic control in responders. No changes were observed in miR-10a, miR-151a, miR-181a, and miR-let-7a.
population_specificity: 49 subjects with metabolic syndrome (23 responders, 26 non-responders based on fasting insulin changes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adding 20% grape pomace to rabbit feed affects production traits, meat quality, fatty acid composition, antioxidant properties, and shelf life compared to conventional feed.
results_summary: Grape pomace improved intramuscular fat percentage, fatty acid ratios, and delayed meat spoilage but did not enhance antioxidant capacity or phenolic content in the meat. Feed conversion rate and carcass yield were negatively impacted.
population_specificity: Thirty-six weaned commercial rabbits (18 per treatment, mixed sexes).
effective_dosage: 20% addition of grape pomace to feed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize and validate sustainable extraction methods for polyphenols from red grape pomace, particularly for cosmeceutical applications, focusing on antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: The study found that the BET-CA formulation (betaine with citric acid) showed good intracellular antioxidant activity (IC50 0.15 ± 0.02 μg mL-1 in malvidin content) and significantly reduced pro-inflammatory cytokine IL-8 release, improving cell viability in injured human keratinocytes.
population_specificity: 3D human keratinocytes (HaCat spheroids) injured with menadione.
effective_dosage: Not specified (tested at IC50 0.15 ± 0.02 μg mL-1 in malvidin content).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary supplementation with dried grape pomace (DGP) on performance, egg quality, biochemical parameters, and antioxidant status in laying hens.
results_summary: Feeding 5% DGP reduced feed intake and egg mass but improved yolk color compared to the control group. No significant effects were observed on egg production, weight, shell quality, or serum antioxidant parameters.
population_specificity: Laying hens (1825 ± 87 g body weight)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a grape pomace polyphenol-based nutraceutical (Taurisolo®) could reduce serum TMAO levels and oxidative stress biomarkers in humans, potentially aiding atherosclerosis prevention.
results_summary: The study found that Taurisolo® significantly reduced TMAO levels (-49.78% at 4 weeks, -75.80% at 8 weeks), oxidized LDL (-43.12% at 4 weeks, -65.05% at 8 weeks), and reactive oxygen species (-34.37% at 4 weeks, -49.68% at 8 weeks), with no significant changes in the control group.
population_specificity: 213 human participants (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of instant controlled pressure drop (DIC) on non-extractable polyphenols (NEPP), extractable polyphenols (EPP), and dietary fiber in grape pomace.
results_summary: DIC treatment at 0.2 MPa-60 s increased total EPP and anthocyanins, while higher pressure (0.4 MPa-120 s) reduced anthocyanins and non-extractable proanthocyanidins due to structural transformations. DIC also partially solubilized insoluble dietary fiber and modified polyphenol profiles, enhancing antioxidant capacities.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or lab-based study implied).
effective_dosage: 0.2 MPa-60 s and 0.4 MPa-120 s (pressure and duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal proportion of grape pomace (GP) in finishing cattle diets by evaluating its effects on nutrient intake, digestion, ruminal fermentation, and nitrogen excretion.
results_summary: The study found that dietary inclusion of GP up to 15% improved nutrient digestibility and nitrogen retention, but beyond this level, nutrient supply and growth performance could be compromised. Effects on ruminal pH and short-chain fatty acids were minimal, but fecal excretion of fiber-bound nitrogen changed significantly.
population_specificity: Crossbred beef heifers (initial body weight: 714 ± 50.7 kg).
effective_dosage: 0%, 15%, and 30% of dietary dry matter (DM) as GP.
study_duration: 21-day periods in a replicated 3 × 3 Latin square design.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of raw and fermented grape pomace on growth performance, antioxidant status, intestinal morphology, and bacterial species in broiler chickens, as well as assess its potential as an alternative to synthetic antioxidants.
results_summary: Fermented grape pomace (FGP) improved body weight, increased serum catalase levels, and reduced cecal Clostridium perfringens counts, while raw grape pomace (GP) enhanced antioxidant enzyme levels and ileum morphology. Neither GP nor FGP affected carcass parameters, breast meat quality, or most bacterial species.
population_specificity: One-day-old male broiler chickens (Ross 308).
effective_dosage: 15 g/kg of diet for both GP and FGP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dried grape pomace (DGP) and dried citrus pulp (DCP) as alternative dietary fibre sources on nutrient intake, digestibility, and utilization in feedlot Angus steers.
results_summary: Steers fed DGP showed higher dry matter intake, nutrient retention, and nitrogen efficiency but lower apparent digestibility compared to DCP. DGP improved nutrient intake and nitrogen utilization more effectively than the control diet.
population_specificity: 7-month-old Angus steers (281 ± 15.7 kg) under feedlot conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to recover bioactive compounds from grape pomace and evaluate the effectiveness of thermosonication in enhancing aqueous extraction rates.
results_summary: Thermosonication at 55°C, 40% amplitude, and 6 minutes yielded the highest extraction of phenolics (11%) and anthocyanins (25%), with superior antioxidant capacity compared to conventional extraction. Encapsulation in alginate-Ca2+ improved stability, particularly in the absence of light.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate grape pomace seed extract-loaded vesicles as a green solution for intestinal delivery, focusing on their antioxidant and prebiotic potential.
results_summary: The study found that glucidex-hyalutransfersomes maintained stability under gastric conditions, counteracted oxidative damage in Caco-2 cells, and promoted Lactobacillus reuteri biofilm formation, suggesting potential as a food supplement for intestinal disorders.
population_specificity: In vitro (Caco-2 cells) and bacterial (Lactobacillus reuteri) models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a herbal preparation containing Aglianico grape pomace (PPP) on rheumatoid arthritis symptoms in a murine model.
results_summary: The PPP preparation delayed disease onset and reduced clinical symptom severity in a collagen-induced arthritis model. Early PPP treatment also lowered serum levels of IL-17, IL-1b, and IL-17-triggering cytokines.
population_specificity: Murine (mouse) collagen-induced arthritis model
effective_dosage: Not specified (PPP extract ratio: 4:1:1 propolis, pomegranate peel, grape pomace)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of thermal pressure, baking, acid, and enzymatic treatments in reducing ochratoxin A (OTA) content in grape pomace (GP) to address safety concerns.
results_summary: Autoclaving reduced OTA by 19-80%, acid treatments showed similar effectiveness, baking increased detectable OTA, and carboxypeptidase A was the most effective enzyme in reducing OTA.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on grape pomace samples).
effective_dosage: Not specified (treatment conditions described, e.g., 121 °C for 10-30 min, 50 °C for 24 h).
study_duration: Varies by treatment (10-30 min for autoclaving, 24 h for acid treatments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of inactivating grape pomace condensed tannins using polyethylene glycol (PEG) on feed intake, physiological, carcass, and meat quality traits in broiler chickens.
results_summary: PEG treatment partially inactivated grape pomace condensed tannins without compromising broiler health, but optimal PEG levels for feed intake, weight gain, and feed conversion efficiency were not determined. Linear and quadratic trends in physiological and meat quality parameters were observed with varying PEG levels.
population_specificity: Male Cobb 500 broilers (two-week-old, 334.6 ± 21.43 g live weight).
effective_dosage: 6.5% (w/w) grape pomace, pre-treated with PEG at 2.5%, 5%, 10%, or 15% (w/w).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize polyphenols in grape pomace extracts and investigate their effects on osteogenic differentiation of human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs).
results_summary: Both red and white grape pomace extracts, despite differing in phenolic composition, enhanced osteoblast differentiation in hMSCs by altering gene expression, including reducing the RANKL/OPG ratio and increasing osteoblast-related genes. The findings suggest potential use of these extracts in dental materials for bone regeneration.
population_specificity: Human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs) derived from bone marrow.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether treating grape pomace with Trametes versicolor via solid-state fermentation enhances its phenolic composition and anti-inflammatory potential.
results_summary: The study found that treatment with T. versicolor increased phenolic acids, flavan-3-ols, and rutin content in grape pomace, except for anthocyanins. This increase correlated with enhanced anti-inflammatory activity, as measured by inhibition of 5-lipoxygenase and hyaluronidase.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grape pomace extract (GE) could protect against cisplatin-induced kidney toxicity in rats.
results_summary: GE worsened cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity, increasing creatinine and urea levels, histopathological kidney damage, and mortality, except in one group receiving pre- and post-treatment with a low dose. GE did not improve antioxidant capacity.
population_specificity: Male Wistar albino rats (64 total).
effective_dosage: Two doses of GE (specific amounts not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of pre-treating grape pomace (GP) with polyethylene glycol (PEG) and a cellulolytic enzyme mixture on broiler growth and meat quality, focusing on mitigating anti-nutritional compounds.
results_summary: Pre-treatment with PEG and enzymes improved body weight gains and carcass weights comparable to the control diet, suggesting successful reduction of anti-nutritional effects. Meat water-holding capacity was higher in the combined PEG-enzyme treatment group (PENZ) compared to others.
