population_specificity: Cobb 500 broilers (initial live-weight 249.2 ± 20.31 g).
effective_dosage: 100 g/kg GP, with PEG (50 g/kg) and/or enzyme (1 g/kg) as pre-treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grape pomace and seed polyphenol extracts could aid in the recovery of gut microbiota diversity and composition after antibiotic and high-fat diet treatment in mice.
results_summary: Grape pomace and seed extracts improved the relative abundance and diversity of gut microbiota compared to spontaneous recovery, particularly influencing Verrucomicrobia and Akkermansia levels. The findings suggest these extracts positively impact microbiota restoration post-antibiotic and high-fat diet exposure.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice fed a high-fat diet and treated with antibiotics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of extended maceration (EM) and additional pomace (Double pomace) on the chromatic, anthocyanin, and tannin composition of Pinot noir and Zinfandel wines.
results_summary: Extended maceration (1 and 6 months) and Double pomace treatments reduced chromatic properties and anthocyanin content but favored large polymeric pigments. Tannin levels increased significantly in 6-month EM wines (13-fold for Pinot noir, 1.6-fold for Zinfandel) but remained unaffected in 1-month EM and Double pomace treatments.
population_specificity: Wine (Pinot noir and Zinfandel) production.
study_duration: 1 month and 6 months for extended maceration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of grape pomace extract (Taurisolo®) and Taurisolo®+pectin on reducing TMAO serum levels in overweight/obese subjects and to validate a new LC/MS method for TMAO quantification.
results_summary: Both grape pomace extract (Taurisolo®) and Taurisolo®+pectin significantly reduced TMAO serum levels by approximately 78% and 77%, respectively, after 8 weeks. The study also validated a precise, accurate, and rapid LC/MS method for TMAO measurement without isotopic internal standards.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese subjects at high cardiovascular risk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the aqueous enzymatic extraction of phenolic compounds from Syrah grape pomace to enhance yield and antioxidant capacity.
results_summary: The enzymatic treatment increased phenolic extraction yield by up to 66% and antioxidant capacity by up to 80%, with tannase and cellulase playing key roles in liberating specific beneficial compounds. The method was also validated across different grape pomace varieties, demonstrating broad applicability.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on grape pomace extracts).
effective_dosage: Not specified (enzyme doses were optimized but exact amounts not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (incubation time was reduced but exact duration not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the TMAO-reducing effect of a grape pomace extract (Taurisolo®) in humans and assess its potential as a natural remedy for cardiovascular risk reduction.
results_summary: The study found that Taurisolo® significantly reduced TMAO levels by 63.6% after 4 weeks compared to placebo, with high intestinal bioaccessibility of resveratrol (92.3%) and detectable levels in serum and whole blood. The results suggest it may be effective in lowering prognostic markers for cardiovascular events.
population_specificity: Humans (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming wine grape pomace flour (WGPF) could improve blood biochemical parameters, including oxidative stress biomarkers, in individuals with components of metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: WGPF consumption significantly reduced glycemia and insulin resistance, increased plasma vitamin C levels, and decreased oxidative damage markers (AOPP and oxLDL), while vitamin E and MDA levels remained unchanged.
population_specificity: 27 male volunteers with some components of metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: 7% WGPF in a beef burger (containing 3.5% fiber and 1.2 mg GE/g polyphenols), consumed daily for one month.
study_duration: Three months (WGPF-burger in month 1, no burgers in month 2, control-burger in month 3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory effects of a synbiotic combination of grape pomace extract (prebiotic) and a lactobacilli mixture (probiotic) in a cellular model of inflammation.
results_summary: The synbiotic combination down-regulated 57.5% of inflammatory genes and 60% of proteins, reduced key cytokines and chemokines, and decreased signaling molecules activated by LPS, suggesting anti-inflammatory properties. The effect appeared to involve the MAPK and NF-κB pathways.
population_specificity: Caco-2 cells (a human intestinal cell line) challenged with LPS.
effective_dosage: Grape pomace extract (50 μg/ml gallic acid equivalent) and lactobacilli mixture (3 × 10^8 CFU/ml total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of grape pomace activated carbon (GPAC) for removing polyphenols from wine wastewater and assess its potential as a sustainable, eco-friendly solution.
results_summary: GPAC showed superior polyphenol removal (84.3%) compared to exhausted grape pomace (48.5%), with maximum adsorption at pH 3.8. The phenol adsorption capacity of GPAC was higher than other reported adsorbents, and desorption of polyphenols was highly effective (91%) using an ethanol-water solvent.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on wastewater treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of grape pomace supplementation on growth performance, nutrient digestibility, blood profile, and meat quality in commercial broilers.
results_summary: Grape pomace supplementation showed quadratic effects on body weight gain during early growth stages, reduced serum cholesterol levels, and improved meat quality parameters, such as decreased lipid oxidation and redness in breast meat. No significant linear effects were observed on overall growth performance or nutrient digestibility.
population_specificity: Commercial broiler chicks (3 days old).
effective_dosage: 5 g/kg, 7.5 g/kg, and 10 g/kg grape pomace supplemented in diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility of extracting cellulose nanocrystals (CNCs) from grape pomace and evaluate their morphology, crystallinity, thermal stability, and toxicity for potential food and pharmaceutical applications.
results_summary: The study found that chemical and physical pretreatments effectively removed non-cellulosic components, yielding CNCs with high crystallinity and thermal stability. Toxicity tests on Caco-2 cells showed CNCs were non-toxic, suggesting suitability for food and pharmaceutical use.
population_specificity: In vitro (Caco-2 cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the metabolites responsible for the effects of phenolic compounds from grape pomace on gut microbiota composition in rats.
results_summary: The study found that specific metabolites, such as 3-hydroxyphenylacetic acid and 2-(4-hydroxyphenyl) propionic acid, correlated with Bifidobacterium growth, while daidzein was linked to Clostridium growth inhibition after long-term intake. The impact of phenolic compounds on gut microbiota appears related to synergistic effects of these metabolites.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various pretreatments on grape pomace to enhance methane production through microbial decomposition.
results_summary: Alkaline treatment with 10% NaOH yielded the highest methane production (0.178Nm³kg⁻¹ of COD), degrading over 50% of lignin and 22% of cellulose. Coupling this pretreatment with freezing at -20°C further increased methane production to 0.2194±0.0007Nm³kg⁻¹ of COD, boosting output by 27% in large-scale digesters.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory-scale batch mode and larger-scale continuous digester).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and purify active compounds from Tinta Cão grape pomace extract (TCEE) that inhibit α-glucosidases, potentially aiding in postprandial glucose control and diabetes treatment.
results_summary: The study identified five major compounds in TCEE that act as potent α-glucosidase inhibitors, suggesting their potential for glucose management. The findings support further testing of these compounds for dietary supplements or diabetes drugs.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of long-term feeding with phenolic-rich grape pomace extracts on rat microbiota and assess potential health benefits.
results_summary: Grape pomace extracts selectively modulated gut microbiota, increasing Bifidobacterium and preventing age-related increases in Clostridium cluster I, suggesting a healthier microbiome phenotype. No significant changes were observed in Bacteroides, Clostridium leptum, or Enterococcus.
population_specificity: 2-month-old rats divided into five groups, including a control group.
effective_dosage: 2.5, 5, 10, and 20 mg/kg/d of phenolic compounds diluted in 0.1% DMSO.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the antimicrobial effects of grape pomace extract, particularly through photoirradiation, in relation to hydroxyl radical (·OH) generation.
results_summary: The study highlights that grape pomace, rich in polyphenols, exhibits prooxidative activity, including antibacterial effects through hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and hydroxyl radical (·OH) generation, especially under photoirradiation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or microbial focus implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the metabolic effects of grape pomace extract (GPE) on mice fed a high-fat diet, focusing on fat mass gain, glucose homeostasis, and gut microbiota composition.
results_summary: GPE reduced fat mass gain, adipose tissue inflammation, liver steatosis, and plasma nonesterified fatty acid levels without affecting food intake. It also improved glucose tolerance, insulin resistance, and gut barrier function while modulating key gut microbiota genera.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize a process for recovering bioactive compounds from white grape pomace and evaluate their antioxidant, anti-tyrosinase, and anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: Ethanol extraction yielded higher phenol levels than water extraction, with dried pomace (DP) showing the highest polyphenol release. DP extracts exhibited superior antioxidant and anti-tyrosinase activities, while anti-inflammatory effects were only detected in water extracts, with wet pomace (WP) showing higher activity.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of enzymatic treatments (tannase, pectinase, cellulase, or a mixture) on the hydrolysis of polyphenolics in grape pomace and its antioxidant activity.
results_summary: Tannase (T) was most effective in increasing total polyphenols and antioxidant activity, while pectinase plus cellulase (PC) and the mixture (TPC) enhanced specific polyphenolic compounds like catechin and procyanidin B2 in different grape pomace types.
population_specificity: Grape pomace from Brazilian wine production (red, white, and mixed varieties).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of hydrochar derived from grape pomace as a sorbent for Pb(2+) in wastewater treatment, particularly after chemical modification with KOH.
results_summary: The study found that KOH-treated hydrochar significantly increased Pb(2+) adsorption capacity from 27.8 mg/g to 137 mg/g at pH 5, with adsorption mechanisms including ion-exchange, chemisorption, and Pb(2+)-π interactions. The process was spontaneous and exothermic, fitting the Sips isotherm model and pseudo second-order kinetics.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on aqueous solutions).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (batch experiments with varying sorbent dosages).
study_duration: Not specified (batch experiments with varying contact times).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of dietary grape pomace on the shelf life of lamb meat, specifically its impact on microbial counts, lipid oxidation, and sensory characteristics.
results_summary: Grape pomace (5% dried) showed a modest (~20%) improvement in reducing lipid oxidation (TBARS values) compared to the control, though this was not statistically significant. It performed similarly to grape seed extract but was less effective than vitamin E in preventing microbial growth and sensory spoilage.
population_specificity: Lamb meat (m. longissimus thoracis et lumborum) from lambs slaughtered at 27 kg live body weight.
effective_dosage: 5% dried red grape pomace per kg of diet.
study_duration: Meat was stored for 14 days post-slaughter; dietary intervention duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether red wine grape pomace flour (WGPF) could reduce metabolic syndrome components in humans.
results_summary: WGPF intake significantly lowered blood pressure, fasting glucose, and oxidative protein damage while increasing plasma tocopherols. No significant effects were observed for waist circumference, HDL cholesterol, triglycerides, total antioxidant capacity, or vitamin C.
population_specificity: Males aged 30-65 with at least one component of metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: 20 g of WGPF per day (containing 10 g dietary fiber, 822 mg polyphenols, and 7258 ORAC units).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the mechanisms behind the antioxidant activity of grape pomace extract (GPE) by assessing its effects on antioxidant enzyme expression and activity in endothelial and muscle cells.
results_summary: GPE significantly increased GCS levels and GST activity in both cell lines but decreased CAT levels and activity only in muscle cells. It had no effect on HO-1 and SOD expression or activity in either cell line, suggesting GSH systems play a key role in GPE's antioxidant effects.
population_specificity: Endothelial (EA.hy926) and muscle (C2C12) cells.
effective_dosage: 2.5 and 10 µg/ml for C2C12 cells; 0.068 and 0.250 µg/ml for EA.hy926 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the release of polyphenols, solubilization of carbohydrates, and antioxidant capacity of grape pomace after enzymatic treatment with carbohydrases and tannase.
results_summary: The study found that tannase and pectinase treatments in grape pomace converted galloylated catechin to its free form, releasing gallic acid and increasing antioxidant activity. Cellulase treatment was ineffective for phenolic release, but carbohydrases degraded cell wall polysaccharides, increasing monosaccharide content.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the antioxidant compounds in Norton grape pomace extract (GPE) and assess its potential health-promoting properties, particularly its anti-inflammatory effects, using a diet-induced obese mouse model.
results_summary: The study found that Norton GPE contained significant antioxidants, including phenolic compounds and anthocyanins, and demonstrated a 15.5% reduction in plasma C-reactive protein levels in high-fat diet-fed mice, suggesting anti-inflammatory effects. However, GPE did not improve oxidative stress markers in the same mice.
population_specificity: Male diet-induced obese (DIO) mice
effective_dosage: Estimated 250 mg/kg body weight per day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize electrically assisted extraction methods to obtain grape pomace extracts with high polyphenol content for potential use as natural antioxidants.
results_summary: The study found that high voltage electrical discharges (HVED) followed by diffusion in 30% ethanol at 60°C for 30 minutes yielded the highest polyphenol content (2.8±0.4gGAE/100gDM) and antioxidant activity (66.8±3.1gTEAC/kgDM). Polyphenol extraction efficiency increased with temperature, following an Arrhenius-type relationship.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: HVED pre-treatment at 80kJ/kg with 5mm electrode distance and liquid-to-solid ratio of 5, followed by diffusion in 30% ethanol at 60°C for 30 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anticancer effects of purified white grape pomace extract (PWGPE) on acute lymphoblastic leukemia Jurkat cells and characterize the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: PWGPE induced apoptosis in Jurkat cells in a time- and concentration-dependent manner, associated with increased p73 expression and downregulation of pro-survival factors. The extract also reduced expression of proteins blocking apoptosis-related genes and induced ROS formation, which was critical for apoptosis.
population_specificity: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia Jurkat cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-diabetic potential of grape pomace extracts by assessing their antioxidant properties and ability to inhibit intestinal α-glucosidase, thereby suppressing postprandial hyperglycemia.
results_summary: The red grape pomace extract showed higher antioxidant activity and stronger inhibition of intestinal α-glucosidase compared to apple pomace. In diabetic mice, oral intake of grape pomace extract (400 mg/kg) significantly reduced postprandial hyperglycemia by 35%.
population_specificity: Streptozocin-induced diabetic male C57BLKS/6NCr mice (6-week-old).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the evidence on the effects of dietary supplementation with antioxidants and phenolic compounds, including Grape Pomace, on milk and dairy products from dairy animals.
results_summary: The abstract does not specifically mention Grape Pomace's effects, but it indicates that supplementation with certain plant-based compounds influenced the chemical composition of milk and dairy products.
population_specificity: Dairy animals (cows, sheep, goats)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of maltodextrinated grape pomace extract (MaGPE) in managing diabetic retinopathy by addressing underlying oxidative stress.
results_summary: The MaGPE group showed improvement in best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) values after 6 months, suggesting potential benefits in managing mild to moderate non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy.
population_specificity: 99 patients with mild to moderate non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of gut microbiota and microRNAs in explaining inter-individual variability in response to grape pomace supplementation among subjects with metabolic syndrome factors.
results_summary: Responders to grape pomace showed lower Prevotella and Firmicutes levels and increased miR-222 levels, suggesting improved glycemic control. The study linked microbiota and miRNA changes to variability in polyphenol response.
population_specificity: 49 subjects with at least two factors of metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize existing knowledge on the bioactivity, potential applications, and chemical composition of dietary fiber from grape pomace.
results_summary: The study highlights grape pomace's rich bioactive phytochemicals and dietary fiber, with demonstrated biological activities including anti-cancer, antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and cardiovascular benefits. Potential applications in various bio-industries were also discussed.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of grape pomace, rich in both extractable and non-extractable polyphenols, on markers of metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: Grape pomace supplementation significantly improved fasting insulinaemia but did not affect other cardiometabolic risk parameters. A tendency toward improved postprandial insulinaemia was observed, particularly in subjects with higher fasting insulin levels.
population_specificity: Fifty subjects (22 women) aged 20-65 with at least two MetS factors.
effective_dosage: 8 g of dried grape pomace daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of grape seed extract-loaded chitosan nanoparticles (GSEx-CHNPs) in treating cryptosporidiosis in immunosuppressed male mice.
results_summary: GSEx-CHNPs significantly improved body weight loss, cleared the infection, and reduced serum cytokine levels, demonstrating anti-cryptosporidial activity, particularly in immunosuppressed mice. The extract contained multiple phenolic compounds and promoted an anti-inflammatory response.
population_specificity: Immunosuppressed and immunocompetent male mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grape seed extract (GSE) could mitigate imidacloprid-induced growth, hormonal, and gastrointestinal toxicity in Nile tilapia.
results_summary: GSE supplementation improved growth indices, serum biochemistry, digestive enzyme activity, body composition, hormonal responses, and reduced oxidative stress in tilapia exposed to imidacloprid. Histological damage caused by imidacloprid was also alleviated by GSE.
population_specificity: Juvenile Nile tilapia (Oreochromis niloticus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the bioactivities of grape seed extract (GSE) and its alkaline-processed version (ATGSE) in treating benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) in an animal model.
results_summary: ATGSE (250 mg/kg) was significantly more effective than GSE in reducing prostate and seminal vesicle weight, lowering PSA levels, and decreasing pro-inflammatory cyto-chemokines in prostate and seminal vesicles.
population_specificity: Male mice with testosterone-induced BPH.
effective_dosage: GSE (500 mg/kg), ATGSE (125, 250, 500 mg/kg) administered orally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanical, antimicrobial, and biocompatibility properties of hydrogels enriched with Grape Seed Extract (GSE) for potential use in dental treatment.
results_summary: The study found that GSE-enriched hydrogels exhibited excellent biocompatibility, no cytotoxicity, and strong antibacterial performance against multiple bacterial strains, with 30 wt% GSE inhibiting over 90% of bacterial growth. However, higher GSE content reduced mechanical properties like elongation and tensile strength.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether grape seed extract (GSE) could mitigate oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, and inflammation caused by antidepressant drugs and quinolinic acid in glial cells.
results_summary: GSE prevented increases in oxidative stress markers (ROS, TBARS, NO), apoptosis, and mitochondrial dysfunction while restoring ATP production and reducing NLRP3 overexpression in glial cells exposed to antidepressants or QA.
population_specificity: BV-2 glial cells (in vitro study)
study_duration: 23 hours (GSE pre-treatment) followed by 1-hour drug exposure
interactions: Interacted with bupropion, imipramine, paroxetine, trazodone, venlafaxine, and quinolinic acid

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the antimicrobial efficacy of grape seed extract (GSE) alone and in combination with cold atmospheric plasma (CAP) against L. monocytogenes and E. coli strains, including their isogenic mutants.
results_summary: GSE showed synergistic antimicrobial effects when combined with CAP, particularly against L. monocytogenes when GSE was applied before CAP, and against E. coli when CAP was applied before GSE. Individual GSE exposure did not inhibit E. coli, but it was effective against L. monocytogenes, especially the ΔsigB mutant.
population_specificity: L. monocytogenes 10403S WT and its isogenic mutants (ΔsigB, ΔgadD1, ΔgadD2, ΔgadD3), as well as E. coli K12 and its isogenic mutants (ΔrpoS, ΔoxyR, ΔdnaK).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grape seed extract (GSE) could mitigate salinity stress effects on faba bean plants by modulating growth, physiology, and gene expression.
results_summary: GSE application significantly improved growth parameters, photosynthetic activity, and antioxidant responses in salt-stressed faba bean plants while reducing oxidative stress markers and modulating stress-related gene expression.
population_specificity: Faba bean plants under salinity stress (150 mM NaCl).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cytoprotective and antioxidant effects of Grape Seed Extract (GSE) when co-administered with dopamine in solid lipid nanoparticles (SLNs) for potential Parkinson's disease treatment.
results_summary: The study found that DA/GSE-SLNs did not alter cell viability, provided cytoprotection against Rotenone-induced toxicity and oxidative stress, and modulated Rotenone-mediated increases in Alpha-synuclein levels.
population_specificity: Differentiated SH-SY5Y cells (in vitro model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Grape Seed Extract (GSE) co-loaded in solid lipid nanoparticles (SLNs) as part of a nose-to-brain delivery system for Parkinson's disease treatment.
results_summary: The study found that GSE-loaded SLNs in slight viscous dispersions (SVDs) facilitated dopamine permeation through nasal mucosa and demonstrated uptake by human nasal cells, with the Poloxamer/Carbopol blend showing better penetration enhancement than the oxidized alginate/HPMC combination.
population_specificity: Nasal porcine mucosa and human nasal RPMI 2650 cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grape seed extract (GSE) could protect against chlorpyrifos (CPF)-induced liver toxicity in rats.
results_summary: GSE prevented CPF-induced liver dysfunction, mitochondrial impairment, oxidative stress, and histopathological damage by regulating CYP450 gene expression and inhibiting DNMT1, suggesting a detoxification pathway.
population_specificity: Rats exposed to chlorpyrifos (CPF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Grape Seed Extract (GSE) on metabolic factors, blood pressure, and steatosis severity in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: The study found that GSE significantly improved insulin resistance, lipid profiles, blood pressure, and hepatic steatosis severity in NAFLD patients, with statistically significant reductions in insulin, HOMA-IR, cholesterol, triglycerides, LDL-c, and liver enzymes, as well as increased HDL-c and QUICKi.
population_specificity: 50 NAFLD patients (25 in GSE group, 25 in placebo group; average age ~44 years, mixed gender).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of silver nanoparticles derived from grape seed extract (AgNPs-GSE) combined with blue laser irradiation in reducing bacterial viability of E. coli and S. aureus.
results_summary: The study found that AgNPs-GSE combined with blue laser irradiation significantly reduced bacterial viability, achieving reductions of 83.80% for E. coli and 87.01% for S. aureus at specific concentrations and exposure times.
population_specificity: Bacterial cultures (E. coli and S. aureus) in a laboratory setting.
effective_dosage: 10 µl of AgNPs-GSE for E. coli; 1 mM, 1.5 mM, and 2 mM AgNPs-GSE for S. aureus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of silver nanoparticles derived from grape seed extract (AgNPs-GSE) combined with red laser irradiation in reducing bacterial viability of Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus.
results_summary: The study found that AgNPs-GSE combined with 405-nm laser irradiation significantly reduced bacterial viability, with reductions of up to 79.53% for Escherichia coli and 85.04% for Staphylococcus aureus at higher concentrations (2 mM) and longer irradiation times (180 s).
population_specificity: Bacterial cultures (Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of cryoprotectants (sucrose and Me-β-CD) in stabilizing solid lipid nanoparticles (SLNs) containing dopamine and grape seed extract for nasal administration in Parkinson's disease treatment.
results_summary: The study found that SLNs with grape seed extract maintained their morphology after freeze-drying, but in vitro release studies showed no GSE release from cryoprotected formulations. Sucrose improved SLN stability better than Me-β-CD, with minimal impact on cell viability.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using RPMI 2650 cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if procyanidin-rich grape seed extract (prGSE) could protect against LPS-induced oxidative stress, epithelial barrier damage, and biofilm formation by Gram-negative bacteria.
results_summary: prGSE reduced LPS-induced permeability alterations and ROS production in Caco-2 cells, inhibited biofilm formation in E. coli and S. Typhimurium, and increased survival in infected Galleria mellonella larvae.
population_specificity: Caco-2 cells (in vitro) and Galleria mellonella larvae (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the therapeutic efficacy of an oral succinyl chitosan-coated liposomal formulation containing grape seed extract in rats with bleomycin-induced pulmonary fibrosis.
results_summary: The study found that the formulation improved weight regain, reduced lung weight and hydroxyproline levels, and ameliorated lung fibrosis in rats. The drug release was pH-dependent, with higher release rates in neutral conditions compared to acidic ones.
population_specificity: Rats with bleomycin-induced pulmonary fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the iron-chelating, antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and hepatoprotective effects of grape seed extract (GSE) in pediatric β-thalassemia major patients receiving deferasirox.
results_summary: GSE significantly reduced serum iron, ferritin, liver enzymes (ALT, AST), inflammatory markers (TNF-α, hs-CRP), and oxidative stress markers (MDA, GSH), while improving TIBC. No significant changes were observed in SOD activity or Hb concentration.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with β-thalassemia major receiving deferasirox.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Grape Seed Extract (GSE) and exercise on Doxorubicin-induced toxicities in the heart, liver, and muscle of healthy rats.
results_summary: GSE partially corrected Doxorubicin-induced oxidative stress, metabolic disturbances, and muscle damage, with greater efficacy when combined with exercise. The combined treatment (GSE + exercise) was more effective than either intervention alone.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiviral effects of grape seed extract (GSE) against norovirus (NoV) using inactivation and binding inhibition tests.
results_summary: GSE demonstrated concentration- and time-dependent inhibition of NoV-VLP binding, with electron microscopy revealing that GSE-treated NoV-VLPs aggregated, distorted, and swelled, suggesting direct interaction with viral particles. The study identified GSE as a potential disinfectant component against NoV.
population_specificity: In vitro study using feline calicivirus (FCV) and NoV virus-like particles (NoV-VLPs).
effective_dosage: Multiple concentrations tested (specific amounts not provided).
study_duration: Treatment times varied (specific duration not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of grape seed extract (GSE) on condylar growth, osteoblast formation, neovascularization, and Type II collagen levels in rats after functional mandibular advancement.
results_summary: GSE alone did not show a statistically significant difference compared to the appliance-only group, but when combined with ADMSCs and LLLT, it contributed to the highest increases in osteoblast formation, neovascularization, and Type II collagen levels.
population_specificity: Rats with functional mandibular advancement

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of low concentrations of grape seed extract (GSE) on osteoblastic cell morphology, adhesion, proliferation, and functional activity.
results_summary: GSE at low concentrations maintained cell morphology, increased cell adhesion and proliferation, and enhanced functional activity (ALP detection, mineralization, and osteopontin expression) in osteoblastic cells, though some effects varied by concentration and time.
population_specificity: MC3T3-E1 osteoblastic cells in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of grape seed extract (GSE) and sodium fluoride (NaF) in remineralizing surface and subsurface enamel lesions.
results_summary: GSE and NaF showed similar effectiveness in increasing enamel microhardness and remineralizing lesions, with no significant differences between the two treatments. SEM and EDX analyses confirmed comparable occlusion of porosities and Ca/P ratios for both groups.
population_specificity: Bovine incisor crowns (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of Grape Seed Extract (GSE) in reducing Listeria monocytogenes contamination on fresh produce and evaluate the impact of food matrices on its antilisterial activity.
results_summary: GSE significantly reduced L. monocytogenes counts on treated produce compared to controls, with higher effectiveness on apples and lower on cantaloupe. A 15-minute treatment was more effective than 5 minutes, achieving reductions of 0.61 to 2.5 log10 CFU depending on concentration, duration, and produce type.
population_specificity: Fresh produce (cantaloupe, apples, celery) inoculated with L. monocytogenes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hepatoprotective effects and mechanisms of action of Manjari Medika grape seed extract (GSE) in mitigating methotrexate (MTX)-induced hepatic damage in mice.
results_summary: The study found that GSE reduced MTX-induced hepatic toxicity, suppressed reactive oxygen species generation, lipid peroxidation, and cellular nitrite formation, and modulated TLR4/NF-κB and Nrf2/HO-1 signaling pathways to restore hepatic health.
population_specificity: Murine (mice) model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether red grape seed extract (RGSE) could mitigate malathion-induced neurotoxicity in rats by assessing its effects on BDNF levels, acetylcholinesterase activity, oxidative stress, and apoptosis.
results_summary: RGSE improved acetylcholinesterase and SOD activity, BDNF levels, and total antioxidant capacity while reducing caspase 3 activity in rats exposed to malathion, indicating it corrected malathion-induced biochemical alterations.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar albino rats
effective_dosage: Equivalent to 12,000 mg fresh red grape seed and 150 mg vitamin C

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate two methods of loading dopamine (DA) and grape seed extract (GSE) into solid lipid nanoparticles (SLNs) for potential Parkinson's disease treatment, focusing on oxidative stress reduction and DA permeation.
results_summary: The study found that GSE coencapsulated with DA in SLNs resulted in smaller particle size (187 nm vs. 287 nm) and higher cellular uptake in olfactory ensheathing and SH-SY5Y cells compared to adsorbed GSE. Both SLN types allowed DA permeation through nasal mucosa.
population_specificity: In vitro (olfactory ensheathing cells and neuronal SH-SY5Y cells) and ex vivo (porcine nasal mucosa) models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the anti-inflammatory effect of grape seed extract (GSE) in animal and cellular models and explore its mechanism of action, particularly in relation to multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: GSE reduced inflammatory cytokine secretion, inhibited Th1 and Th17 polarization, improved clinical symptoms in EAE mice, and prevented spinal cord demyelination and microglia activation. It also downregulated TLR4 and ROCKII expression, further suppressing inflammation.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice with experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a model for multiple sclerosis.
study_duration: From the 3rd to the 27th day after immunization (24 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of grape seed extract (GSE) in enhancing the therapeutic effects of mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) transplantation for type I diabetes, and to compare the efficacy of specific GSE components (procyanidins-B1 and P-C1) with whole GSE.
results_summary: GSE combined with MSCs significantly improved glucose and insulin homeostasis, reduced inflammatory markers, and alleviated oxidative stress in type I diabetic rats. The co-treatment also promoted beta cell regeneration.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced type I diabetic rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Grape Seed Extract (GSE) could reduce the multi-directional toxicity induced by potassium bromate in Allium cepa L.
results_summary: GSE administration at two doses (465 mg/L and 930 mg/L) significantly reduced potassium bromate-induced toxicity, improving physiological, cytogenetic, and biochemical parameters, with the higher dose showing the most pronounced effects.
population_specificity: Allium cepa L. (onion) bulbs

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate the virucidal activity of grape seed extract (GSE) against murine norovirus (MNV), a surrogate for human norovirus, to explore its potential as a treatment for norovirus infections.
results_summary: GSE showed dose- and time-dependent virucidal activity against MNV, causing viral particle aggregation and eliminating pathogenicity in an animal model at 50 µg/mL for 10 minutes.
population_specificity: Murine norovirus (MNV) as a surrogate for human norovirus, tested in an animal model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the curative effects of grape seed extract (GSE) in an experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) mouse model of multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: GSE treatment corrected the clinical course of EAE, reduced mechanical hypersensitivity, and prevented thermal cold allodynia. It also decreased oxidative stress, restored antioxidant enzyme activities, normalized myelin protein expression, and corrected glial protein overexpression and sirtuin downregulation.
population_specificity: Six-week-old female C57Bl/6J mice subjected to the EAE paradigm.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antimicrobial efficacy of grape seed extract mouthwash against chlorhexidine and a control in reducing plaque microorganisms and periodontal disease severity.
results_summary: Grape seed extract mouthwash significantly reduced microbial CFUs and improved clinical parameters compared to the control, with efficacy similar to chlorhexidine. No significant changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: 45 undergraduate students aged 18-30 years.
effective_dosage: 2% grape seed extract mouthwash (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grape seed extract proanthocyanidins (GSPE) could counteract aristolochic acid-induced liver injury in rats.
results_summary: GSPE showed protective effects against liver injury by reducing oxidative stress, increasing antioxidant enzyme activity, and inhibiting apoptosis via the PI3K-AKT pathway. The intervention group exhibited improved liver function and reduced markers of cellular damage compared to the aristolochic acid group.
population_specificity: 32 Sprague-Dawley rats divided into four groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether MegaNatural®-BP grape seed extract could maintain normal blood pressure in adults.
results_summary: One study showed an effect on blood pressure after 6 weeks of consumption, while a second study found no effect after 8 weeks. The evidence was insufficient to establish a cause-and-effect relationship.
population_specificity: Adults with normal, high normal blood pressure, or stage 1 hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the suitability of Grape Seed Extract (GSE) in a bioadhesive polymeric patch for wound care, focusing on its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antimicrobial properties.
results_summary: The study found that GSE-loaded patches demonstrated mechanical resistance, sustained release, and concentrations sufficient to stimulate keratinocyte growth, exert antibacterial effects, and provide antioxidant activity. The optimal patch formulation used a 9.5/1.0 AG/PVP ratio combined with cyclic dextrin for molecular dispersion.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or preclinical study implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardioprotective effects of grape seed extract against aluminum phosphide poisoning by assessing its impact on oxidative stress biomarkers in human cardiac myocyte cells.
results_summary: Grape seed extract (100 g/l) reduced oxidative stress biomarkers in poisoned cells, recovering Malondialdehyde (56%), Catalase (0.71%), Protein carbonyl (74%), and Superoxide dismutase (51%), though its efficacy was lower than taurine.
population_specificity: Human Cardiac Myocyte cells (in vitro cell line model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of grape seed extract (GSE) and its procyanidin fractions on inflammation and oxidative stress caused by H. pylori in human gastric epithelial cells.
results_summary: GSE and its fractions significantly reduced IL-8 secretion and intracellular ROS production in H. pylori-infected cells, demonstrating anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects. They also exhibited antibacterial activity against multiple H. pylori strains.
population_specificity: Human gastric epithelial cells (AGS) infected with H. pylori.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of grape seed extract in lowering glucose, lipid levels, and blood pressure across diverse populations.
results_summary: Grape seed extract significantly lowered total and LDL cholesterol in subjects with hypercholesterolemia, T2DM, or metabolic syndrome after four weeks and may reduce systolic and diastolic blood pressure in hypertensive or metabolic syndrome patients.
population_specificity: Subjects with hypercholesterolemia, T2DM, metabolic syndrome, or hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grape seed extract (GSE) could mitigate age-related cognitive decline by enhancing hippocampal neurogenesis, synaptogenesis, and reducing dark neuron production in aged mice.
results_summary: GSE significantly increased hippocampal neurogenesis (DCX+ cells) and synaptophysin expression while reducing dark neuron frequency. Behavioral tests showed improved memory and learning performance in the GSE-treated group.
population_specificity: Aged mice
